items.message:
The Flood Alert has now been removed. The risk of flooding has now reduced. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, but there may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
 
Our incident response team is continuing to monitor the forecast and situation on the ground. The weather forecast remains unsettled for the rest of the week and further rainfall is expected along with strong winds. 
 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Continue to take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

items.description: South Cornwall coast at Mounts Bay, seafront properties
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Peak spring tides from the weekend have passed, however the risk of coastal flooding increases again from Wednesday.

Storm Ciaran is set to bring strong winds, significant waves and a tidal surge leading to an increased risk of coastal flooding. Key tides of concern are on Wednesday evening, 1st Nov at 18:42 and Thursday morning, 2nd Nov at 07:00. The times given are for Newlyn and will vary along the coast.  

Possibly significant wind and wave overtopping could result in dangerous conditions on the coastline with the potential for fast flowing water. Take care near the coastline and do not drive through waves or flood water.  Please continue to monitor your local weather conditions and take care in the areas of concern. 

We are monitoring the situation. Please check online for updates.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lands End to Lizard Point excluding Mounts Bay
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Peak spring tides from the weekend have passed, however the risk of coastal flooding increases again from Wednesday. 

Storm Ciaran is set to bring strong winds, significant waves and a tidal surge leading to an increased risk of coastal flooding. Key tides of concern are on Wednesday evening, 1st Nov at 18:42 and Thursday morning, 2nd Nov at 07:00. The times given are for Newlyn and will vary along the coast.  

Possibly significant wind and wave overtopping could result in dangerous conditions on the coastline with the potential for fast flowing water. Take care near the coastline and do not drive through waves or flood water.  Please continue to monitor your local weather conditions and take care in the areas of concern. 

Locations particularly at risk include Mousehole, Praa Sands and Porthleven. 

We are monitoring the situation. Please check online for updates.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding Truro City
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Peak spring tides from the weekend have passed, however the risk of coastal flooding increases again from Wednesday. 

Storm Ciaran is set to bring strong winds, significant waves and a tidal surge leading to an increased risk of coastal flooding. Key tides of concern are on Wednesday evening, 1st Nov at 19:28 and Thursday morning, 2nd Nov at 07:39. The times given are for Truro and will vary along the coast.  

Possibly significant wind and wave overtopping could result in dangerous conditions on the coastline with the potential for fast flowing water. Take care near the coastline and do not drive through waves or flood water.  Please continue to monitor your local weather conditions and take care in the areas of concern. 
 
Low lying areas along the Helford & Fal, including A39 at Perranarworthal & exposed coastal locations including Portmellon seafront, Mevagissey Harbour area & Portholland are particularly at risk. 

 We are monitoring the situation. Please check online for updates.

items.message:
River levels are forecast to be high as a result of high spring tides.  Areas most at risk are Keadby, Amcotts, Owston, Burringham, Gunness, Althorpe, East Butterwick, Flixborough, Gunness Lane and, Neap House road. Flooding is possible in this area. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding.
We expect river levels to remain high on spring tides until 01/11/23. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 01/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are forecast to be high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels.  Flooding continues.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.  Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
We expect river levels to remain high on spring tides until at least 01/11/23. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 01/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Warning has been removed. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk at high tides. The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land. We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: Flooding is possible in this area. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

River levels are now steadily falling, but still remain quite high in some locations. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Further rain is expected later this week. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued by the Environment Agency. 

Flood Alert in force: Tern and Perry catchments. 

Flooding is possible for: Rivers Tern, Perry, Roden, Strine and Meese and their tributaries.

Be prepared.

Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

items.description: River Witham and associated Fens from Washingborough to Metheringham
items.message: Following Storm Babet and subsequent heavy rainfall, water levels in the Witham Catchment remain high, but are now receding. We are actively monitoring the bank of the river near Fiskerton village, and have installed cameras to monitor the location continuously. We have agreed an action plan with the Local Resilience Forum should circumstances change. We urge residents in Fiskerton village, Short Ferry Caravan Park and properties along Ferry Road area to remain vigilant, and stay up to date with the latest advice. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

The Flood Warning has now been removed. The risk of flooding has now reduced. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, but there may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
 
Our incident response team is continuing to monitor the forecast and situation on the ground. The weather forecast remains unsettled for the rest of the week and further rainfall is expected along with strong winds. 
 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Continue to take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: South Cornwall Coast from Rame Head to Wembury Bay including tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Peak spring tides from the weekend have passed, however, the risk of coastal flooding increases again from Wednesday.

Storm Ciaran is set to bring strong winds, significant waves and a tidal surge leading to an increased risk of coastal flooding. Key tides of concern are on Wednesday evening, 1st Nov at 19:51 and Thursday morning, 2nd Nov at 08:02. The times given are for Plymouth and will vary along the coast. 
 
Possibly significant wind and wave overtopping could result in dangerous conditions on the coastline with the potential for fast flowing water. Take care near the coastline and do not drive through waves or flood water.  Please continue to monitor your local weather conditions and take care in the areas of concern.
  
Notter Bridge, Embankment Rd Plymouth, Torpoint Ferry Terminals & Noss Mayo are particularly at risk.  
 
We are monitoring the situation. Please check online for updates.

items.description: South Cornwall Coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Peak spring tides from the weekend have passed, however, the risk of coastal flooding increases again from Wednesday.
 
Storm Ciaran is set to bring strong winds, significant waves and a tidal surge leading to an increased risk of coastal flooding. Key tides of concern are on Wednesday evening, 1st Nov at 19:51 and Thursday morning, 2nd Nov at 08:02. The times given are for Plymouth and will vary along the coast. 
 
Possibly significant wind and wave overtopping could result in dangerous conditions on the coastline with the potential for fast flowing water. Take care near the coastline and do not drive through waves or flood water.  Please continue to monitor your local weather conditions and take care in the areas of concern.
 
Fowey Fore Street, Town Quay, Albert Quay & Caffa Mill Car park, Lostwithiel Quay Street & Recreation ground, Polperro Harbour & Quay Rd, The Quay at Looe & the B3247 at Seaton are particularly at risk. 
 
We are monitoring the situation. Please check online for updates.
